captions.text:
Welcome to How To Cook That
I am Ann Reardon

This weeks dessert and after many many requests
is tiramisu.

Now if you are new to how to cook that we
have dessert one week, followed by cake followed

by chocolate and you can put your requests
in the comments below.

To make your tiramisu first you need to put
your egg yolks and sugar into a bowl and whisk

them together. For the printable copy of the
recipe with all of the recipe quantities that

you need just go to the website howtocookthat.net
there is link in the description below the
video.

Then put a saucepan on the stovetop with a
little water in the bottom and let it boil.

And then rest your bowl on top of the saucepan
so that it traps most of the steam underneath

the bowl. So that it gently heats up those
egg yolks and sugar.

Continue to stir those and what we are doing
here is we are heating up the egg yolks so

that we can cook them and we can basically
kill any bacteria off. So we need to keep

stirring it once its got hot for about 10
minutes to allow time for that to happen.

Then we want it to be completely cool. So
to speed up that process I like to place the

whole bowl into a sink of cold water and just
stir it occasionally until it's cold. Once

it is cool it will look like this. It will
be pale it will be thick and it will create

ribbons as it falls back into the bowl.
When you lift up that whisk you just see those

ribbons going back into the mixture. At this
point you want to add your mascapone cheese

and fold it through using a spatula.
Now if you do this while your mixture is still

warm the mascapone is just going to melt so
you don't want to do that it has to be complete

cold before you stir it through.
If you can't buy mascapone cheese where you

are, you can make it using cream. If you take
600ml of cream and add 3 teaspoons of lemon

juice and stir it together. Then heat that
up until its just at boiling you can do that

in the microwave. And then pour into coffee
filters and have them sitting in a sieve.

ANd then put the whole thing in the fridge
overnight. Now the result will not be as thick

as store bought mascapone so while it is fine
to use in this dessert it would not be suitable

for use in frosting recipes because it still
has too much water in it.

Now you need to make your coffee mixture and
this is where the real variation in flavours

comes in. You can add some marsala, you can
leave it plain and you can make it as strong

as you want it. Then take your sponge finger
biscuits or salvadori and dip them into the

coffee. I just like to dip them quickly and
take them out, the longer you leave them the

more they will absorb and the stronger coffee
flavour your dessert will have.

The coffee mixture also where you can vary
how strong this desserts going to be. You

need 1 cup of liquid and I've made it four
times as strong as you'd make a normal cup

of coffee and this will only give you a mild
flavour in the dessert. So if you want that

intense coffee hit with each mouthful you
need to make it really really strong.

Place a layer of the fingers across the base
of your dish, and then cut them down to size

if you need to to make them fit neatly. And
then spread over a thin layer of that thick

mascapone mixture. Then add another layer
of fingers.

If you are serving this dessert to kids then
I suggest you use decaffinated coffee and

skip the marsala. You can make your own sponge
fingers for this recipe but unless I am making

a gluten free version for one of my friends
with coeliac disease then I just use store

bought ones because they are convenient and
they are easy to use.

Add another layer of mascapone followed by
fingers and topped with a final layer of macapone.

You can top your dessert with a sprinkle of
cocoa powder or if you are like me you might

prefer to put milk chocolate on top. To make
that just temper your chocolate spread it

out on a tile or the bottom of a clean baking
tray and let it just start to set up at room

temperature. ANd then use a spoon and run
it across the top leaning the spoon forward

will help you get some sort of rough curl
and if you lean it back more you'll get more

fans of chocolate. Then sprinkle that over
the top of your dessert. Refrigerate that

for at least a couple of hours to let it set
up before serving.

If you want to make individual serves you
can dip the fingers into the coffee mixture

and then just put them on a plate to let it
soak in a bit. Place them onto a clean plate

and pipe dots of the mixture across it, top
with the next one, add dots of the mixture

on top of that and then just top with a strawberry
and some chocolate on either side.

I like to add a strawberry on top just so
you have that contrast in colour just take

your strawberry cut off the green bit and
then slice down but not all the way through

the strawberry. And then do that in equal
portions across it and then you should be

able to fan it out and then you can put that
on top of your tiramisu slice. Join me next

week for the chocolate sphere tutorial off
the instagram cake and if you are new to How

To Cook THat make sure you subscribe, there
is a new video every friday and you can put

your requests in the comments below. Have
a great week, Bye [music by youtube.com/setsailtv]

title: Tiramisu Recipe HOW TO COOK THAT Dessert Ann Reardon
